resharedPost.text:
LunaBill (YC F25) is the AI call center for healthcare billing teams.

The US healthcare system runs on phone calls. An estimated 25M phone calls happen each week between hospital systems and insurers.

The average medical biller spends 70% of their time chasing insurance companies, waiting on hold, and following up on claims.

That‚Äôs why at LunaBill, they're building AI voice callers for healthcare billing teams.

LunaBill‚Äôs AI voice callers manage claim status checks, denial and appeal follow-ups, and on-call reprocessing. Since launch, they've partnered with several leading U.S. health systems to automate 50,000+ phone calls, saving them over 20,000 hours.

Congrats on the launch, Suhail Parry, Yash Raj Singh Thakur, and David Day!

üöÄ https://lnkd.in/g2knKikP

data.text: This is incredibly valuable use case. Congratulations Suhail Parry and others!

resharedPost.text:
Killer joint Healthcare AI GTM dinner between Phonic and Kaizen Automation, featuring startups like Kaigo Health (YC F25), Careforce (prev. Helpcare AI), Arini, Paratus Health, and others.

Excellent Japanese-Italian fusion, excellent conversation, and some neat lessons:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Most people's phone calls still haven't passed the "Audio Turing Test" -- they can still tell it's an AI, and this is causing meaningful harm to their voice AI businesses.
2Ô∏è‚É£ The need for multilingual is real: some businesses have more Spanish call volume than English, and there's a strong gap between English vs. other languages.

Phonic is at the center of both of these challenges -- with us, our customers are building voice AI agents that are more realistic, faster, and conversational than anything else.

Reach out if you'd like to book a demo!

data.text:
Why stay behind-the-curve on voice AI with out-of-date, robotic models that barely feel human?

Phonic has been cooking. Reach out if you'd like to book a demo!

Every investor‚Äôs got scars from the ones they missed. Ours? Together AI.

Everything about it looked right. Brilliant team, perfect timing, trusted people around us saying it was a no-brainer.

And what did we do? Spent way too much time debating the valuation and told ourselves we were being ‚Äúdisciplined.‚Äù

Fast forward‚Ä¶ and it‚Äôs a multi-billion-dollar company.

Meanwhile, we‚Äôre on the sidelines like the guy who sold Bitcoin at $200 and won‚Äôt shut up about how smart he was.

Great companies almost always look too expensive at the start. That‚Äôs part of why they‚Äôre great - they‚Äôre already bending the market around them.

If it feels obvious and affordable, odds are it‚Äôs not changing the world - although there are plenty of examples of this not being the case, so I won't die on this hill‚Ä¶

That miss stung, but it reminded us there‚Äôs a fine line between discipline and fear.

Discipline is passing on something because it doesn‚Äôt fit your strategy. Fear is passing because the number makes you uncomfortable.

One protects your downside. The other guarantees you‚Äôll sit out while history gets made.

We‚Äôll still miss again - everyone does. But hopefully the next one isn‚Äôt another billion-dollar loss. üòÖ

resharedPost.text:
We just raised $4.75M in seed funding led by Bain Capital Ventures (BCV), with participation from AI leaders at Anthropic, ServiceNow, Salesforce, Meta, Atlassian, and PagerDuty.

Echelon AI builds autonomous AI developers that let IT teams finally move at the speed of business, starting with ServiceNow.

In conversations with 50+ CIOs, we heard the same story again and again. 

The business constantly demands new workflows, custom apps, and critical enhancements on platforms like ServiceNow, SAP, Workday. 

But IT teams are stretched thin and development backlogs often stretch 6+ months.

This velocity gap is a competitive disadvantage. AI changes everything.

Over the past 3 months, we've deployed our AI ServiceNow developers in production at F500 organizations. 

The transformation is dramatic.

At one organization, our AI developer is already #3 on the team by amount of work delivered. 

Our customers deliver 2x more work every sprint, with higher quality. Projects that took months now complete in days.

-

I‚Äôm very grateful to all our customers for trusting us, to our team for bringing our vision to life and to Aaref Hilaly, Rak Garg and our angels for backing our vision from day one.

Huge thanks to Michael Nu√±ez from VentureBeat for covering our launch. Link to his brilliant article in the comments below. 

- 

If you‚Äôre a ServiceNow platform owner with a huge backlog or a services partner looking to transform your delivery model, we‚Äôd love to chat.

resharedPost.text:
The Massachusetts Institute of Technology has always been at the forefront of innovation. This weekend at HackMIT 2025 was no exception.

My observation? Everything's agents. The AI platform shift has opened the floodgates, and like in the dot-com and mobile eras, today's "Agent for X" is disrupting every industry.

The problem? Integrations are hard. I was bombarded by attendees interested in Kaizen. So I talked about one of my favorite customers, powering the front desk of a major casino in Las Vegas!

When the front desk gets a call, "Hey I need towels in room 13050," our customer's AI agent answers the phone with Vapi, Retell AI, Bland, or Phonic. The hard part? Inputting the request into the hotel's legacy system, to dispatch housekeeping.

Our customers use Kaizen to instantly integrate into websites without APIs. Kaizen clicks on buttons, fills out forms, and submits requests like a human. It's a busy hotel, servicing requests every few min, and Kaizen gets it right every single time.

Hospitality, Trucking, Healthcare, you name it ‚Äî Kaizen is automating all repetitive work done on the computer.

data.text: It's always fun being on campus -- HackMIT was such a wonderful time

resharedPost.text:
Big news: we‚Äôre announcing Maven Voice.

Maven Voice is our enterprise-grade AI voice agent built for the chaotic, noisy and unpredictable situations we encounter everyday. 

People don‚Äôt speak in perfect prompts. We change our minds mid-sentence, switch languages without warning, and reference screenshots we sent three emails ago.

And no one wants to hear ‚Äúpress 1 for this, and 2 for that‚Äù when they‚Äôre already frustrated. 

Maven Voice understands your problem, your language, your accent, and responds like a real support agent. We‚Äôve tested it in subways, airports, and stadiums so it adapts like a seasoned pro with a consistent, even-keeled, natural tone that handles interruptions and keeps up with the conversation. 

On the tech side, we made sure it can plug-and-play with telephony, CCaaS & CRM platforms and deliver seamless agent handoff, all powered by Maven‚Äôs orchestration engine. We partnered with the best in the business to give our customers flexibility to pick the right voice engine for their brand. 

Thank you to OpenAI, Phonic, ElevenLabs, and Cartesia for helping make this possible.

Thank you and congratulations to the incredible team behind the most advanced voice AI agent in the world: Joyce Wong Phan, MBA (Product), Rosie Levy Riste (SE), Tammy Lee and Dalya Browne (Marketing), brendon puntin, Jeremy Joslin and Dongsheng Wang (Eng), Eniola Oluwole (UX), and Aimee Allen (CX).

üé• We had a ball bringing this to life in this üëánew video showing Maven Voice in action. 

Details in the comments.

resharedPost.text:
üö® Spotlight on Arun üö®

Meet Arun, MIT grad, IOI ü•à medalist, CS & Linguistics double major

‚ùì What led Arun to Phonic? Arun did a lot of audio research during his M.Eng & really liked the vision

‚ù§Ô∏è Favorite part of Phonic? Being able to work on a variety of things with high velocity & really take ownership

üî• Best part of Phonic culture? A friendly and open team & being able to take responsibility over decisions

When I joined Cruise in 2015, the business model was building a highway autopilot sensor system that people could buy and attach to their cars. Even as a new grad with no business sense, I realized this made no sense. I joined Cruise anyways because the founders were A+ and vibe was great

When I joined Scale in 2018, 90%+ of revenue was concentrated in labeling for self-driving cars. There was no clear path to revenue elsewhere, and focus for the foreseeable future was capturing the self-driving labeling market. Coming out of Cruise, I was extremely bearish on this. I joined Scale anyways because the founder was A+ and vibe was great.

The point? When evaluating the exponential business potential of a Series A/B company, most people far overrate the importance of having a master plan that makes sense from year 1, and far underrate the importance of having a top tier leader who will find a way to find a way

(of course, there's always luck involved, this is a sample size of 2, yadda yadda, but the point stands)

data.text:
‚ÄúThe point? When evaluating the exponential business potential of a Series A/B company, most people far overrate the importance of having a master plan that makes sense from year 1, and far underrate the importance of having a top tier leader who will find a way to find a way‚Äù

Strongly agree with Richard.

At Modal, we put developers first.

When we heard developers at Harvey, Suno, Profound, Phonic and Achira were building batch processing on Modal -- we asked them how we could make them even more productive. We listened to their problems, and designed the right solution.

So today, we're launching Modal Batch.

It's an entirely new durable queueing system that can handle 1 million pending inputs, guarantees execution for up to 7 days and takes just one line to launch.

Best of all, it benefits from Modal's existing infrastructure, allowing you to spin up a thousands containers at short notice. No infra setup needed.

Check out the blog post in the comments!

author.headline: Building dev tools at Modal Labs

data.text:
In 2025 I went all in: I quit my job, left a beautiful life in NYC, and moved to San Francisco. 

Along with my longtime friend and classmate Ken Acquah, I‚Äôve co-founded Kaizen. With Kaizen, we are ushering in a new wave of *software that does work* leveraging computer use agents ü§ñ.

Kaizen is a *no-code browser automation platform*, enabling rapid integration with any website. We are attacking a $250B+ market of outsourced labor, with over 8 million jobs, many of which are simply reading data and submitting forms in online portals. This is the underbelly that powers huge industries like medical billing, financial compliance, and transportation logistics.

Fast-growing AI companies are already using Kaizen to automate entire jobs. Kaizen enters orders into niche ERPs, reads visit data from legacy EHRs, and extracts property information from 1000s of government websites.

For me this is a full-circle moment. At the age of 16 I started programming at the MIT Computer Science and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory (CSAIL), where I spent 6 years deep on information retrieval and question-answering research. I became intimately familiar with the challenges in web scraping and deeply versed in many of the state-of-the-art techniques. The latest improvements in computer use agents have completely revolutionized this field, and I am so excited for what we‚Äôre building at Kaizen.

Need an integration done yesterday into an application without APIs? Book a demo to get access at kaizenautomation.com.

data.text:
Launching Ventrilo.ai: Autocomplete for your thoughts

Humans grasp context intuitively.¬† Machines don't.¬† Outside the tech bubble, most people have yet to develop the skills to steer complex AI effectively.¬† AI needs rich context to be truly helpful.

That‚Äôs why we believe humans will be deeply in the loop for the foreseeable future. At Ventrilo.ai we‚Äôre building tools that empower everyone to work smarter with AI, starting in the browser.

Introducing Ventrilo.ai: Autocomplete for your thoughts

It's designed for accessibility:

üí° It Gets Context: Ventrilo.ai automatically uses relevant context from your browser --- with your permission and control ‚Äì to offer pertinent writing assistance, bridging difficult context gaps for you.

‚úç It's Intuitive: It integrates AI seamlessly into your writing flow. No complex prompting needed ‚Äì just type and it autocompletes your thoughts. Our simple sidebar chat is also available for quick brainstorming, summarization, and analysis.

üîí It's Secure: Your context, your control. Our commitment to privacy and security is foundational (SOC2 compliant). We don‚Äôt serve ads or sell your data. Our business model is designed to align with user value, not to extract from it.

We believe everyone should have access to powerful, easy-to-use AI assistance.

üíº Sales professionals can use Ventrilo to research prospects, personalize their messaging, and accelerate their outreach.

üî¨ Researchers can use Ventrilo to create reports with the context from their open tabs, summarize papers, and generate insights.

ü§ù Recruiters can use Ventrilo to quickly respond to emails and quickly draft personalized messages.

We believe everyone should have access to powerful, easy-to-use AI assistance. This writing assistant is our first step in making practical AI accessible to all professionals.

üëâ Get the Ventrilo.ai Chrome extension: https://ventrilo.ai

(Wondering about our pivot from AI for software testing? We‚Äôll be following up soon with the story of our journey. Stay tuned! Follow us on LinkedIn: https://lnkd.in/gdAZiwiW)

Huge thanks to our team that has shown adaptability, brilliance, and grit: Connie C., Dennis Li, Michael Wehner, Alessa Cross, Adam Howard, Aleksandr Lopashev, and Stefano Cayre.

And props to our investors Andreessen Horowitz, Elad Gil, 11.2 Capital, Bloomberg Beta, Conviction, Rain Capital, and Lachy Groom for their unwavering support on this new mission. Also a shout out to our fantastic angels and advisors Martin Casado, Kurt Keutzer, Dave Park, Dawson Engler, Kevin Wang (FOSSA), Caleb Sima, Chenxi Wang, Ph.D. Junfeng Yang, John Kodumal, Dennis Chou, Gerta Malaj, Moin Nadeem, Jennifer Johnson, Mona Sabet, Russ Andersson, Mehran Farimani, John Whaley, Mike Morris, Billy Hoffman, Zack Smocha, Andreas Kuehlmann, Michael Donohue, Shawn K., Sarah Guo, Waheed Qureshi, Wally Cheng, and Cheng-Ling Chen.

We're hiring! https://ventrilo.ai/about

üéôÔ∏è Voice AI is evolving faster than you think! Key insights from SF Voice AI meetup that will reshape conversational AI:

1Ô∏è‚É£  HuggingFace's FastRTC architecture is enabling dramatically more realistic AI Voice Agents - the days of robotic voices are numbered.  Thank you Freddy Boulton for the great overview!

2Ô∏è‚É£  Phonic's custom speech-to-speech models aim to solve the reliability challenges that have held voice agents back.  Congrats Moin Nadeem and Nikhil Murthy!

3Ô∏è‚É£  Community innovations like the smart-turn detection model (https://lnkd.in/giKRCFuc) are creating more natural conversation flows.

The investor & technology leadership panel with Lee Edwards (Root Ventures), Paige Bailey (Google DeepMind), Radhika Malik (Dell Tech Capital), and Roseanne Wincek (Renegade) delivered a bold prediction: by year-end, we'll see AI coding agents surpassing even elite human engineers.

Fascinating to see 3 of 4 panelists coming from technical backgrounds - this technical depth clearly shapes their focus on developer-centric startups and unique insight into emerging innovation.

Special thanks to Kwindla Hultman Kramer for expert moderation and his exceptional "Voice AI & Voice Agents: An Illustrated Primer" (https://lnkd.in/gE98pu4b) - a must-read resource for anyone in this space!

The real highlight? Connecting with brilliant builders like Tobiah Rex, Chris Nolet, Ryan McKinney, Ricardo Marin, and Yas Morita to tackle both technical challenges (conversation state management, response quality, latency) and business hurdles (prospect targeting, simplified onboarding, regulatory navigation).

As voice becomes the next frontier for AI interaction, these connections and insights are invaluable. 

Who else is building in the Voice AI space? Let's connect!

Great to see other Voice AI founders and investors in the Voice AI meetup in SF last night. Here is my note:

‚úÖ  Phonic is building a foundational model for speech-to-speech, not only achieving a low latency, but also natural voices for conversational AI. Congrats Moin Nadeem Nikhil Murthy (and Podonos is proud of helping Phonic)
‚úÖ Freddy Boulton from Hugging Face gave a live demo of FastRTC and Gradio for AI conversation
‚úÖ Lee Edwards, Paige Bailey, Radhika Malik, Roseanne Wincek: Voice AI is moving forward at an amazing speed. Assume the AI is perfect, find the right market and products. 

Many companies jumped onto foundational voice models, truly multi-lingual speech-to-speech models, voice evals, and verticals. Excited to work in this market.

And thank Kwindla Hultman Kramer for regularly organizing this event üôè

author.headline: Founder/CEO Podonos | Automated analysis for AI model builders | YC alum | ML PhD Georgia Tech

data.text:
Why shouldn't speaking with a AI be as seamless and as reliable as speaking to a human?

Meet Phonic, the next-generation speech-to-speech platform solving exactly this problem.

We‚Äôve all gotten stuck speaking on the phone to an AI that doesn‚Äôt understand you.

At Phonic, we‚Äôve rethought the whole stack from model training to voice evals to compound systems for reliability.

‚ö°¬†We trained our own audio foundation models, letting us focus on reliability during both training and post-training. These models are conversational and exhibit exceptionally low latencies, replying to speech within 300ms of the user sending it. See some conversations attached below!

üí°¬†Phonic learns and improves with every call. The platform imitates successful calls, determined by rigorous automatic evaluations, improving success rates over time. As a result, users can spend less time encoding edge cases, since the Phonic platform will do it for them.

ü™¢¬†Compound models outside of the main voice model asynchronously guide conversational state towards goals, enabling users to tackle longer, more complex calls that are currently out of their reach.

We‚Äôre fortunate to be funded by Grace Isford and Brandon Reeves at Lux Capital and angel investors including:
- Clem Delangue ü§ó from Hugging Face
- Amjad Masad from Replit
- Qasar Younis from Applied Intuition
- Erik Bernhardsson from Modal
- Michele Catasta from Replit
- Douwe Kiela from Contextual AI

Interested in learning more?
Read about our vision here: https://lnkd.in/g-UJv-as 

Check out TechCrunch's feature of us: https://lnkd.in/dysutxNz

If this future resonates with you, either as a customer or as an engineer, sign up for a chat here: https://lnkd.in/gmZKDCba! We‚Äôre excited to bring reliability to voice agents.

Next week I launch what I've been (quietly) working on for the past year: Glenwood. If you'd like to follow along:

https://lnkd.in/ggg_ZCRZ

resharedPost.text:
when you get 2 developer advocates in a room together they COOK

In other news, here's 5 things we learned from 5 open-source LLM demos at our event with Mistral AI last week ü§∫

Phonic: frontier speech-to-speech technology is unbelievably fast
Andon Labs (YC w24): there is massive opportunity for domain-specific agent evals beyond math and coding use cases
Refuel: structured data extraction is a prime use case for few-shot learning because it's fast and easy for humans to provide feedback
Skysight: based on large-scale testing, LLM-generated code can be malformed, but is typically not malicious¬†
Cleanlab: there are two flavors of uncertainty you should know about that cause LLMs to hallucinate: aleatoric and epistemic

Thanks to everyone who attended! Let us know who we should host an event with next üëØ‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

resharedPost.text:
I just finished a four-month ML engineering internship working on text-to-speech AI at Phonic! I really appreciate the team for making this a fantastic experience. They were great communicators and always quick to review and offer feedback when needed, but they also gave me the freedom to identify issues, propose solutions and have ownership over the things that I built.

Some things I did:
	‚Ä¢	Built an automated model evaluation pipeline that reports metrics on Slack during training
	‚Ä¢	Implemented on-the-fly filtering for streaming datasets, enabling deterministic training and resumption
	‚Ä¢	Incorporated audio transcription and vocoder models into training and evaluation
	‚Ä¢	Downloaded and compiled a new audio dataset for training¬†
	‚Ä¢	Built user interfaces and databases for easy human evaluations of models

I especially wanted to thank the cofounders: Moin Nadeem who initially reached out to offer an interview, and Nikhil Murthy who was an amazing intern supervisor. Both of them gave extremely helpful guidance for both my code and my career path as an engineer. I had a great term working here and I would encourage anyone reading this to apply if they are interested!

data.text: Excited to have Colin from UWaterloo join us for a Fall co-op :)

Announcing Ventrilo.ai and our $10m Series Seed

I recall the spring of 2003 fondly. I was splitting time between Palo Alto and San Francisco, finishing up my doctoral thesis on static code analysis. Within the span of a few months, I graduated from Stanford, co-founded my first company, and married my high school sweetheart. It was a pretty good spring.

Based on several years of research in the lab, Coverity was a commercial success soon after launching. Our core idea was to simulate how a human developer thinks about code and report defects in a way that a developer could understand. It was not based on AI but rather a more traditional approach called static analysis. Static analysis could process millions of lines of code quickly and precisely, but it had a huge drawback: it could only tell you where things looked wrong from the perspective of code, but it could not explain how the software would behave when it was run.

That brings us to today. Rapid advancements in LLMs and other AI technologies have made it possible to simulate human perception, thinking, and agency to a degree never seen before. We are on the cusp of AI that can simulate how humans interact with user interfaces. Such an AI is not only possible, but inevitable‚Äîbut not automatically useful, safe, or accepted.

In the near future, AI will help developers test user interfaces and eliminate the need to create and maintain tests. And in turn, developers will teach AI what are acceptable uses for their applications. This will lead to a new way to not only test user interfaces, but have AI safely operate them as well.

To fund this idea from zero to one, I‚Äôm excited to announce our $10m series seed led by Andreessen Horowitz, with participation from 11.2 Capital, Bloomberg Beta, Rain Capital, and Conviction, along with Elad Gil and Lachy Groom.

With this new funding, we‚Äôre hiring! We‚Äôre building a focused team on tackling technical challenges at the intersection of LLMs, agents, web crawling, distributed systems, and graph algorithms. If you‚Äôre an ambitious developer looking for a new challenge and/or have been impacted by the recent industry downsizing, come join us and help build the future. Contact us at careers@ventrilo.ai.

Twenty years ago I had a dream to teach machines how to understand software like a human developer. Today, with AI, we can take that dream to a whole new level.

https://ventrilo.ai
